1.14.text:
“What are you wearing underneath?”
“You can’t be a feminist and be wearing

3.37.text:
that.”
“Go back to your own country!”

5.28.text:
“Are you a terrorist?”
“Islam is so oppressive.” I don’t know

8.66.text: what Islam you’re even talking about B.”

13.68.text:
“Are you a ninja?”
Do you want me to show you what a ninja does?

20.84.text:
I think it’s more offensive to actual ninjas…
I have been called “ninja” many a time.

25.49.text:
Because we have no actual skills at all.
But I did take kickboxing.

28.58.text:
I wish I was. It would be so sick innit.
“Ninja” is not the trend at the moment,

33.43.text:
it’s more of the “Terrorist” one.
And the thing is, when people stare, I don’t

36.77.text:
mind because I’m like, ok it’s something
different.

38.26.text:
I just smile.
How do you smile?

43.52.text:
Ok, “Are you being forced to wear that?”
Are you?

47.89.text:
I think that’s a common question.
I like curiosity, that’s a nice thing. But

53.19.text:
the element of ignorance, just really annoys
me.

56.14.text:
It’s so much better to just say, “Oh,
why do you, why do you wear that?” Open

59.74.text:
questions are beautiful.
Modesty is a really big part of our religion.

62.38.text:
Hijab is basically like, covering.
We describe this as a niqab.

66.64.text:
The headscarf is a hijab. But what we both
are wearing, the whole thing, is called hijab.

71.39.text:
I think some women are actually having to
fight to be able to wear it.

74.73.text:
And the truth is we are a minority within
a minority.

77.59.text:
Maybe in other countries people are being
forced.

79.36.text:
Because what happens is people see Muslim
women. And Muslim women in Sudan, Muslim women

82.50.text:
in Saudi, Muslim women in Nigeria, Muslim
women in Canada.

84.49.text:
We’re not a monolith culture. Why is it
that we’re all connected to the rest of

88.80.text:
the entire world and have to answer to the
1.6 billion Muslims in the world.

95.30.text:
“You’re so lucky you don’t have to wear
make-up.”

98.42.text:
To be honest, yes.
I mean I do wear make-up, you just can’t

101.39.text:
see it.
I never wear any make-up, ever.

103.09.text:
The niqab is so practical.
I just put my face veil on and just go.

107.28.text:
Less time, isn’t it.
Once upon a time I used to cake.

110.11.text:
I have come across lots of niqabis, and everyone
is at different levels, at different stages.

116.98.text:
I had the Naked palette, I had Anastasia palette.
Literally, you name it…

121.23.text:
I saw this really really really funny thing
in someone’s like, yearbook. She was a niqabi

125.66.text:
and under her little description she said,
“I only wear this to give you other girls

130.54.text:
“Go back to your own country!”
Oh child, you didn’t say that to me!

136.88.text:
To Canada?
I was born here, where am I going?

140.77.text:
I wouldn’t have anywhere to go!
I’m Pakistani and I’ve never been to Pakistan.

145.51.text:
Do you appreciate British values?
I have fish and chips, I can make a good fish

149.44.text:
and chips. I can make a wicked batter, without
beer. I use sparkling water.

152.34.text:
What about the peas? You’ve got to have
peas.

154.18.text:
No what about the curry sauce?
When it’s a problem, something happens.

156.52.text:
But when you want your curry, when you want
your samosas, when you want your glitter,

159.19.text:
when you want to put bindis on your forehead
to go to Wireless Festival, it’s all good.

161.89.text:
Were you born in Whipps Cross?
Yeah.

165.24.text: Yeah. Let’s go back there bruv.

170.20.text:
This is going to rile you up.
“You can’t be a feminist and be wearing

173.62.text:
a burqa.”
If anybody was to say that to me they would

176.54.text:
be like, “Oh she is the biggest feminist
you can find.”

178.37.text:
I’m treated like the Queen in my home. And
every woman should be treated like that.

182.32.text:
It doesn’t make sense to me because you’re
sitting here and saying, “Oh but you’re

185.91.text:
oppressed, we want to help you and want to
do this.” But you’re not letting me do

189.77.text:
what I want to, you’re not letting me be
free.

192.28.text:
Yes there are some cultural practices that,
maybe oppresses women. But there it’s cultural,

199.07.text:
it’s never been Islamic.
No it’s not.

201.57.text:
If feminism is about a woman making her own
choices, then this is one of them.

206.12.text:
And by the way, we don’t undermine a woman
who does not wear the face veil or the hijab,

211.15.text:
at all. I respect her completely.
No way. Yeah.

217.18.text:
“Don’t all your photos look the same?”
I think I have the same face, it should look

223.32.text:
I have an Instagram feed right, and it’s
banging.

226.56.text:
I take photos without my niqab on.
Yeah we get dressed up, we curl our hair.

231.02.text:
I am into the fifties vintage dresses.
We put make-up on, we look good.

236.51.text:
A lot of people kind of say, “Oh you look
the same, how can you tell this person from

241.78.text:
that person?”
It’s the eyes, we all have different eyes

243.88.text:
Yeah. And that’s how you know it is.
And that’s how you know when the friendship’s

251.13.text:
true. When you can tell who they are through
the niqab.

258.61.text:
“What are you hiding there?”
A bomb.

261.00.text:
There are so many people who are wearing clothes.
They’re wearing jackets, they’re wearing

265.17.text:
hoodies. Does everybody have a bomb underneath?
This bomb thing, it has been said to me many

270.08.text:
times.
ISIS will come for me, do you understand?

272.54.text:
Exactly, exactly.
They don’t care. They don’t care about

274.69.text:
if it’s Tom, Dick or Harry. If it’s me,
or if it’s some Fatima or Bilal in the street,

279.90.text:
they will go for them as well.
I remember, you know when something happened

283.17.text:
in the media, instantly as soon as a conversation
came up when people wanted to talk about it,

287.08.text:
I became ready to defend my religion. That’s
not okay.

290.84.text:
It’s not our problem. We don’t know why
they did it, and it’s got nothing to do

294.54.text:
with us. You know people come and ask me,
you know “Why did your people do that? Why

298.26.text:
is ISIS like this?” I don’t know! I’m
not ISIS!

299.26.text:
“Your people” as well. They’re not my
people, we’re not boys.

300.26.text:
I assure you I’m not hiding anything, honestly
like, I have a life to live.

303.42.text:
Speak to me, listen to my laugh yeah. That’s
the first thing you need to do to know I can’t

308.41.text:
“Why would you wear that?”
That’s a question I like, and I respect.

314.79.text:
I am wearing it for God. It’s my own spiritual
journey…

318.81.text:
Because in the end of the day, this is just
a piece of cloth…

321.15.text:
It’s an act of worship, and I love doing
it. And I live it.

326.95.text:
But it’s why it that gives me purpose.
It’s is who I am, this is my identity.

331.26.text:
Yeah there has been times in my life when
I considered taking it off.

335.10.text:
I do appreciate in this country, that we do
have the right to be able to wear it.

338.79.text:
The stares I get, the comments I get in the
street. But it had also to do with my own

343.13.text:
Muslim community, where I struggled.
It’s not just Muslim women who are modest.

346.47.text:
They’re are so many different religions
and different types of people who practice

350.72.text:
modesty in different ways.
This is something that I feel, whenever I

353.30.text:
do it, I feel that spiritual thing in my heart,
and it just boosts me up.
